results.title: Doing Time for Patsy Cline
results.brief_description: Following a passion for country music, Ralph leaves his father’s sheep farm in a remote Australian town, armed with a guitar and a plane ticket to Nashville, Tennessee. He hopes to hitchhike to Sydney Airport where his take-off into a successful country/western singing career will hopefully begin. However, fate and his naivety find him hitchhiking with a psychotic drug thief named Boyd, and Boyd’s mesmerising girlfriend, Patsy. The plot then splits into a series of parallels, flash forwards and flashbacks. One depicts Ralph’s imprisonment after being framed for drug trafficking. The other follows the dramatic ascent of his career to hype status and the pairing between the dynamic Patsy and himself.

results.title: Doing time for Patsy Cline
results.creator_credit: Chris Kennedy, John Winter and Oilrag Productions
results.brief_description: Ralph, a country boy who has just left his parents farm to seek fame and fortune as a country singer in Nashville, hitches a ride with a drug dealer, Boyd, and his girlfriend Patsy. Within 24 hours Boyd and Ralph are arrested and locked up in a country jail. Set against a background of country music and shifting between the present and Ralph’s daydreams, in which he fantasises about finding success in Nashville with the alluring Patsy, the film embraces the bittersweet pathos that characterises the country music genre. Cast includes Richard Roxburgh, Miranda Otto, Matt Day, Tony Barry and Kiri Paramore.

results.title: Doing time
results.creator_credit: Bruno Boulianne, Eric Michel, National Film Board of Canada and Society and Science Studio
results.brief_description: This documentary traces the experiences of a group of inmates in Bordeaux Jail who are participants in the radio show, Souverains anonymes. Under the guidance of Mohamed Lotfi the inmates are given an opportunity to express themselves in regular studio activities where their need to be heard, catalysed by the jail environment and their experiences before and during their imprisonment, is nurtured and given form through words. A portrait of daily prison life and the inmates that participate in Lotfi’s program, a varied, sometimes tragic, sometimes hopeful picture of prison life and the circumstances that brought each person there is evoked. Through interviews with inmates, footage of the studio sessions and interviews with Lotfi and professional guests to the program this documentary investigates the drive for and discovery of freedom through language and the release of personal expression.

results.title: Doing the bus stop
results.brief_description: A safety education program using song and dance routines pitched at 8-12 year olds, to demonstrate safe behaviour on and around buses in the country and city. Hale, a “radical” driver, takes Tess on a mystery tour to illustrate vital skills which will ensure the safety of children who use public transport.

results.title: Doing it our way, according to our culture
results.creator_credit: Frances Gallagher, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Growing up in a mission, Frances Gallagher had disjointed access to her own culture and found it hard to navigate the world outside. By looking into her past, and through her years of community work, Frances sends a strong message of the importance of empowerment and self-determination. Essentially, a community is much stronger when they can manage their own affairs, their way and according to their culture and beliefs.

results.title: Doing business in Japan
results.creator_credit: Business Council for International Understanding and Vision Associates
results.brief_description: This film deals with the difficulties and complications that arise, in international business relationships, as a result of the cultural barriers that exist. The film is designed to be a teaching/training tool that can be used as the focus of a discussion or course of study.

results.title: Doin' what the crowd does
results.creator_credit: Peter Wallach, Jane Warrenbrand, Scott Newman Foundation and Peter Wallach Enterprises
results.brief_description: This uniquely animated musical film tells us that teenagers don’t necessarily have to follow the crowd, but can think and act for themselves. Exuberant young people dance, sing and perform athletic stunts on a city playground. Within the dance two peer groups interact, one enticing with drugs, alcohol and cigarettes, the other “doing what’s right for me”. The film is open-ended to provoke wide ranging discussion from the audience.

results.title: Dogwatch
results.creator_credit: Laurie McInnes, Richard Brennan, Black Ray Films, Smile Production and AFFC
results.brief_description: From the director of “Broken Highway”, “Dogwatch” is a thriller set at sea aboard a rusty cargo ship with equally as dubious a crew. Captained by alcoholic and corrupt skipper (Steven Vidler) aka ‘The Judas Captain’, the doomed ship is to be sunk by Heckle, the first mate (John Brumpton) once the captain has navigated the vessel to deep waters - all paid for by Triad gangsters. The hapless (sometimes farcical) crew and mysteriously cryptic Palmer (Russell Kiefel) make the journey unbearable for the captain. Stopping off to do a bit of gun smuggling in exchange for gold, the crew discover a stench in the hold and as one crew member points out ‘The Triad’ that organised this cruise won’t be expecting anyone to return. Mutiny and murder take over the minds of the crew as each man tries to assert his will and survive the situation in which they find themselves. Written and directed by Laurie McInnes. Cast includes Richard Carter, Joel Edgerton, John Alansu, Yaw Glymin.

results.title: Dogtown and Z-boys
results.creator_credit: Stacy Peralta, Agi Orsi, Vans Off The Wall and AOP
results.brief_description: 1975 and in a slum area of Santa Monica, California, was located a rough neighbourhood know as Dogtown. In Dogtown, twelve teenage friends, many from broken homes, zealously surfed their dilapidated well-protected turf. Known as the Zephyr Boys - or Z-Boys for short - these teenage boys and one girl, applied their well-honed surfing skills to skateboarding and a fad that had all but died out was reborn. Fuelled by competitive drive and pushing each other to perform increasingly daring feats, the crew were inspired when a chronic drought left innumerable swimming pools empty. It was in these empty pools that the Z-Boys skated (illegally) and devised unheard of manoeuvres, revolutionising the sport. When “Skateboarder” magazine chronicled their audacious adventures, fame and notoriety beckoned. Whilst competing in the revived National Skateboarder Championships, the tricks performed wowed those present and the Z-Boys ruled. This documentary uses extensive stills and footage from the era (some of it quite astounding) and intersperses it with contemporary interviews with the Z-boys, who reminisce about their glory days and the forces that shaped their destiny. MTV style editing, a plenitude of vintage material and a rocking soundtrack (including Ted Nugent, Black Sabbath, Led Zepplin The Stooges and Jimi Hendrix) makes for great viewing.
